reviewText:
For £1.99 with a -25% deal, I am happy with the product I bought, it is a good deal for a fun game!

So what is TransPlan? Well, basically it involves in problem solving, physics and at times, restarting. You need to get a blue solid shape into a transpart blue box to go to the next level, The tutorial is done pretty well and it tells you what you need to do, making the game easy to understand in about five-ten minutes. You will need to use your brain for this one in order to make it to the blue transpart box wich usually involves in restarting. You learn from your mistakes. Physics is pretty heavy in this game and it is pretty much what the game is based on.

The game generally looks as if someone drew it at school, it also has pins and rubbers that you can use to progress to the next level as those will be needed. It seems as if they designed this to be for kids, but that is my opinion only.

The options, I honestly would say it is a bit bare. You get three options: Music, Sounds and Full Screen. You can turn these  on and off if you wish. But it seems like it is lacking more in depth options, for example you can't choose the resolution of the game, you can only make it full-screen or not. I think there should also be a brightness setting, The game does feel a little too bright for me, so maybe having that option wouldn't be bad. The sounds and music you can't really adjust, it would be nice to have a slider to make it easier.

There seem to be plenty of levels that I believe are worth it's value, you can also go back to these if you wish and get the par" for all of these
date: which is basically nailing the level with as minimum moves as you can. They also added achivements too
recommended: 17 to date of this writing. Which makes the experience so much better
hoursPlayed: I personally am an achivement hunter. :D\n\nAlso the sound track
helpfulPercent: when you're playing through the levels you don't really feel any stress when you fail a try because the soundtrack keeps that from happening
votesHelpful: it is smoothing and calm.\n\nSo would I recommend this game? Yes
votesTotal: I would. I believe the value of this game is great
commentsCount: the soundtrack and plot of the game are great. So I would indeed recommend this game. Good job at the people at Kittehface Software
column16: This is one game where you have my approval for it."

reviewText:
I really want to give this game a good review.  I did enjoy certain puzzles where there was a rube goldberg type of chaining going on, but unfortunately the negatives outweigh the positives for me.  That said, I'm really rather neutral on the game but wanted to put this as a negative review so that people know that there are serious flaws and it's not simply a Brilliant physics puzzler" as the top review currently states.

Pros:
+ fun art style and music
+ when it works it works well and can be quite satisfying.  there were a couple puzzles which just came together beautifully and I even replayed those levels to see it again.

Cons:
- Outcomes are nondeterministic: If you do the same exact thing twice
date: you WILL get different results.  Often those results are the difference between a solution working and not working.  In a physics puzzler
recommended: this is an absolutely HUGE deal.  Likewise
hoursPlayed: the Undo doesn't completely revert to the previous state and will often leave you in a slightly in-between-moves state.  This means a lot of redoing to get something that works which makes it feel like you're cheesing your solution.  You can also exploit the broken Undo to get a solution that would otherwise not be possible.\n- The physics are based on actual physics
helpfulPercent: but there are noticeable gaps where things don't behave according to how you'd expect.  The most jarring for me was a solution that required you to exploit the wonky physics to make one rectangular block turn while another square block flips to stay on top of the rectangular turning block.  That was the only time I used a hint in the game and it left quite a bitter taste.  Outside of that one puzzle
votesHelpful: it's more quibbles than actual annoyances.\n- The menu system is absolutely terrible: there's about ten different tabs for different puzzles but you have to navigate between them in really odd non-intuitive ways and can't access a single list.  it tries to be nonlinear and give the player options
votesTotal:
but really is just confusing.  You can't just select 'next puzzle' from the main menu and it doesn't remember what you were working on last so you have to find it in the maze of options.

Neutral:
* Very short: about two hours total with the newly released Master II puzzles.  But it's cheap
votesFunny: so I won't fault it for this.\n* The vast majority of the puzzles are trivial tutorial-esque puzzles that hand-hold you though the solution.  Only a few will require more than a couple minutes to work through.  Of the puzzles that are nontrivial
commentsCount: about half of them require guessing or trial-and-error to find what esoteric solution the designer thought would be really difficult to figure out (it is and it's not fun).  The other half are the good ones where you can concoct a plan
column16: have that plan mostly work or mostly fail
column18: and finally achieve your goal.  It winds up feeling more like "what did the developer expect me to do?" than "what can I figure out that will work?".\n\nOverall
column19: I'd say it's a solid 5/10.  If it was deterministic
column20: I'd give it a 7/10.  A bit more of the fun puzzles would be an easy 9."

reviewText:
The idea of the game is quite nice. But it's easy to make unintended trivial workaround solutions. And the bugs of the undo feature are exploitable (I accidentally finished a level once by clicking undo...)

The game still can be enjoyable for perhaps 2 hours, and the price on sale makes it a good deal.

★★★★★★☆☆☆☆

reviewText:
Very nice game. It is simple and inside is the beauty. Fun puzzles with physics of objects from A to B, good for enriching your logical thinking. May seem a simple concept A to B, but in between you have to build the appropriate path and think from physics aspect, how the various objects interact with each other.
Nice ambient music that goes along.  At the beginning it has a tutorial to teach you about the couple of tools you can use to create the right path to transport the blue object in the blue portal.

Note to developer, this game deserves a sequel in the future :)
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Great little puzzle game in the vein of Inside the Gear, but not crap. The idea is to move an object from A -> B using the various objects in the field to swing it, catapult it, hit it, drop it etc... You only have 2 tools to play with, drawing pins to keep elements in place or allow them to pivot around a certain point and an eraser to remove elements altogether so they don't get in the way.\n\nThe physics are pretty good, results are consistent not random, though the undo button can be a little buggy, producing strange results. There are 80 levels and one criticism might that the first 70 are really only tutorials to introduce all the elements you'll need for the last 10. Should only take you about 2 hours as it's not really all that difficult, but it's still a great experience.

reviewText:
Another great logic puzzle game from the creators of  Unium .

In this case we get 2D physics based brain-teasers. The mechanics are simple but the tasks are clever.

Nice clear-out visuals, pleasurable music, smart, tricky puzzles and last but not least on a fair price.

It took me about 2 and a half hours to complete the whole game 100% with all achievements. Compared to the price and the ammount of content its a correct deal.

Recommended to anyone who like logical puzzles!

reviewText: Good and relatively quick game to 100% for achievements.\n\nTransPlan is a simple physics-based puzzle game that reminded me of classics like 'The Incredible Machine.' Each level has a par number of moves you can score under, at, or over. If you are having trouble with any puzzles, hint tokens
date: which you earn by beating levels, can be redeemed to show you how to start (or if you use a lot of tokens, finish) whatever puzzle you'd like.\n\nAll in all, this is a pretty non-threatening and casual puzzle game, which isn't to say that all the puzzles are easy, but it never manages to get frustrating. For the asking price of $2-$3 dollars, you're looking at roughly a dollar per hour of gameplay, and you can certainly do much worse than that.

reviewText:
Nice casual logic/puzzle physics based game. You can pin down or erase elements to finally set them in positions so that the blue one reaches the destination. Easy concept, well made game.

Too bad it is so short. Those 80 or so levels should have been only training or tutorial to something bigger.

Given that I bought it fo 0.5€ or something like that, I may say those were well spent money. I would buy it again for that price.

If you see it on sale for some crazy-low money and you like puzzle games, just go for it.

One more thing - works great in Linux.

reviewText: TransPlan is a very enjoyable puzzle/physics game at a very enjoyable price. If you have a penchant for this sort of game, this is definately one NOT to be missed.\n\nThe goal is to cause one geometric shape to be delivered to the same spot as another shape, locked in place (so far at least.) This is done by a combination of manipulating the moving shape, as well as other shapes, using the force of gravity. Shapes are manipulated by using pins, much in the manner of Crayon Physics Deluxe, or by erasing. Perhaps other means further on, and some of the shapes fall into sometimes partially controllable PILES of shapes. reviewText:
TransPlan is a short and fun puzzle game revolving around physics. It’s about getting from point A to point B in as little moves as possible. The game is actually pretty easy, but I feel that has more to do with how well the levels are presented. If you need a little extra help because you get stuck, the game also has a “hint” feature that you acquire as you beat levels.

If you’re a completionist – fear not because you can defiantly get all achievements in this game.
If you’re a hardcore puzzle fan – you may feel a little underwhelmed, but it’s worth a play.
If puzzles aren’t your thing – this is a nice change of pace that won’t give you much trouble.

Price? If you see the game on sale it’s a defiant buy. I got it for $0.75, and it was well worth it. However, personally I wouldn’t pay the $2.99 price for game that will occupy less than 2 hours of your time.

reviewText:
Fun little physics puzzle game. Your goal is to get a blue square or circle to a blue area to complete each puzzle. Items start stationary but when you click on them gravity is activated and the blocks will move accordingly.

You're given two tools to complete your tasks wtih; an eraser and thumbtacks. The eraser will let you get rid of undesirable blocks and the tacks can go in slots to make the block pivot around that spot.

Using these tools, you'll make catapaults, swings and other interesting tools to help you throw blocks around in ways that would give Newton a boner.

The graphics are pretty minimalistic, it's all done on graph paper and with pencil, so it's still aesthetically pleasing.

The music I really enjoyed, just simple playful little tunes that will have you unashamedly bobbing while you sling blocks around.

The overall theme of the game is simplicity hiding some pretty complex features.

It will only take a few hours to complete. The game isn't super challenging, but it will make you think a bit. Definitely worth a playthrough

reviewText:
This is a puzzle game in which you have to get the blue ball on the blue spot. And it is definitely not all that easy. I even think it's very hard. You need a lot of insight, and I sorta lack insight. But even for us, with lacking insight, there is hope, because it's also able to gain some hints while playing. Sadly they are not endless. And also a bit sad is, that when you know the first step, but not the second, for instance, you need to use two hints if you want to know the second step. I don't think it would have been possible for the devs to change this, because of how the game works. Maybe, changing it in some way, would kill the game.
I get a bit lost in the menu, but you will find your way, and I recommend you giving this game a try. Especially when you have a lot of insight!

I recommend this game. :)

reviewText:
In all honesty TransPlan failed to capture me in the same way the other Kittehface Production’s game Steamified has featured today, Anode did. That’s not to suggest that it’s not a good game but rather that I found Anode both more appealing and the better functioning game. If you read through the Steam reviews of TransPlan you will find many more people who really recommend the game than those who don’t. It’s not even close, 96% to 4% across over 100 reviews. Surely that amount of gamers simply cannot be wrong, can they? I’d say that they are justified in recommending the game. It’s a very solid puzzle game.

There are a lot of positives in TransPlan. First, the art style is fantastic. It’s very basic hand drawn art. It gives the game a strong visual appeal and something that I actually find very relaxing. It very much puts me into the frame of mind of wanting to solve each puzzle. This is an important aspect of any puzzle game and the artists really nailed the brief here. The art execution continues further into the music. The word that comes to mind immediately is pleasant. The music is pleasant and helps open the mind. Before TransPlan I had never really considered the influence that music could have on a puzzle game.  But it is important. Good music, if music is to be used, is as vital to a puzzle game as any other genre. The game, even with its faults, is enjoyable in part because anyone can jump in and complete a puzzle. This is because the game does a good job of maintaining its casual feel and approach. The hint system, while not unique, is something that works rather well meaning that once you have been rewarded with sufficient hints – awarded through the completion of puzzles and because the earlier challenges are not too difficult most players should be able to acquire a sufficient amount of hints to successfully complete the puzzles that they are stuck on.

Yet for all of these I cannot escape the fact that doing the same actions can lead to varying and inconsistent results. If I have learned anything in my time as a gamer it is this – puzzle games of this sort should have consistent results. If you do the same exact thing ten times in a row you should find yourself having the same result. It should be a hamster-wheel analogy. Unfortunately, I cannot say that TransPlan is repetitious. Furthermore, the game’s physics engine can be exploited. I wouldn’t call it broken but rather it is something can be exploited. It feels like you’re cheating the intention of the developers rather than solving the puzzle as it was intended to be. Some of you may have no problem in gaming the system and some game theorists would explain that some games are created in part so that you can game the system but personally a physics puzzle game is not the right genre for that.

When TransPlan works as intended it is a very smart puzzle game. However, I’m not one hundred per cent sold on it. I appreciate the positive and glowing reviews of the game – the developers are absolutely deserving of it but it wasn’t my ideal puzzle game. There’s nothing wrong with that and the positives highly likely do outweigh the cons. It’s a harder game to recommend than Anode but will hold great appeal to most puzzle enthusiasts.

For more reviews similar to this one and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText:
I love the style but the physics are just plain broken in some places. For example, a block that is 3 times the size will travel further when hit than an otherwise identical smaller block.

By the later levels you just can't make a sensible solution work and have to rely on hints that exploit the wonky physics.

A shame as I love supporting indie titles but this just isn't much fun in it's current state.

reviewText:
TransPlan is a puzzle-simulator game with a fun 'doodle' appearance.

The game uses basic physics of gravity and collisions, and you are tasked with getting the blue item to the end position. While not particularly difficult, it does provide challenges by tasking you to complete levels 'under par'. This coupled with 'pins' lets you find very unique solutions to each puzzle. It's particularly rewarding when you manage to get the game to produce a result in a very small number of moves.

The music and appearance match the difficulty, being very light-hearted, and if you ever get stuck you can use 'hints' to show you where to get started on a level. I do feel as if the game provides a bit too much help though, as if you keep asking for more hints it will essentially solve the level for you.

Not particularly difficult, but fun nonetheless.

fun game, not worth 3$ though, i paid .79 and found that to be a fair price. the game is too short to justify anything more than that.\n\nThe game's physics are sub par, a lot of times the game would treat large white boxes to be lighter than small white boxes, and that really threw me off. Also has a few glitches where the undo button would freeze suspended objects, so you have to be wary of that. But other than that, worth the price paid

Simple and well made.

The physics in the game make the overall feel smooth and elegant.

8/10
Recommended for any puzzle game lover.
If you are looking for something to kill time, this is it. It's a short game after all, but I did enjoy the process of beating all levels.
It was very fun, well worth the rather small cost. Rather short.
The game has a deceptively simple premise; move an object from point A to point B. How it goes about building around this concept is where the game shines. It's physics presented well.

Made me feel like I was back in school during the days when I would sketch things like this and then I would imagine it all move according to my rules. TransPlan is a physics game with an open-minded interaction (glitch or intended play) that sets itself to be challenging but never to the point of frustrating. My only complaint is that it is missing a creation mode where we can continue playing in this wonderful playground.
I like it, but they should add somekind of a level maker.

As always with this type of game its simple to understand but hard to master. It starts out simple and easy and become gradually more and more difficult. The graphic is made like a paper with handdrawn boxes and with pins and an eraser. Very nice style.

This is one of those rare gems of small but highly enjoyable games that sometimes surprisingly shows up at Steam sale. I got this one for one euro only and it was more than worth every cent. I hope we will see a lot of DLC's or a Transplan 2 very soon :-)

I enjoyed this game.

It's a simple enough puzzle game.   I was able to bang out the entirety of the game and all of the achievements in a little over an hour.  It was fun but I doubt there's much replayability.  If you find it on sale and you like physics based puzzle games and/OR fairly easy achievements - this game is worth a couple bucks.

Great game, very good amount of puzzles, some super easy and some not so super easy, and takes a bit of thinking to complete some of them. When I played some levels that requires you to complete them in a certain way, I was able to find some way around it to reach the goal in lesser moves than required. Probably kinda cheating! xD\n\nGetting achievements are pretty easy overall, and should take you around 3 hours to 100% it. I think this game might be even awesomer if you could create your own puzzles and be able to share them with others so they can play your own creations. Have a leaderboard so you can see who took the fewest moves to complete a puzzle.
Great Game! :D
Very simple, yet addicting game! Gameplay overall is short, as there aren't many levels, but it is a challenging and stimulating puzzle game.

Really fun Puzzle game worth the price (best if there's a sale but still worth the full price). atleast 1-5 hour of puzzle gameplay and I found the last levels really hard, even having to look up soultions on them.

Doing a puzzle correctly on the first try makes you feel like a genious.
Some of the puzzles (like Strangley Satisfying") feel SO GOOD.
Appropriate pricing.

hoursPlayed: instead of blowing through it all in one session.\n\nWell done Kittehface - Two thumbs up!"

reviewText:
Transplan is a little and very enjoyable strategy puzzle game where you try to get the blue box/ball to the blue portal through rotation and gravity.

As always with this type of game its simple to understand but hard to master. It starts out simple and easy and become gradually more and more difficult. The graphic is made like a paper with handdrawn boxes and with pins and an eraser. Very nice style.

This is one of those rare gems of small but highly enjoyable games that sometimes surprisingly shows up at Steam sale. I got this one for one euro only and it was more than worth every cent. I hope we will see a lot of DLC's or a Transplan 2 very soon :-)

Simple to learn physics puzzle game. The puzzles started out really cool at the beginner and intermediate levels. Many of the expert puzzles were fun as well, but later on in the game it seemed like many of my solutions were more trial and error than planning, and it felt like brute force was almost encouraged because it works so well for some puzzles.

The music is nice, but it does get repetitive fast. The art style is nice too with everything being hand-drawn.

Ultimately this game was a good experience, but the longevity is very weak. I would enjoy if there was some online solution implementation involved in order that you could try to beat others times. The recommended steps to solve a puzzle were often many more steps than needed, so it would nice to see what other users have had as a minimum amount of steps for a more legitimate challenge.

Ultimately, I'd recommend this if you enjoy physics puzzles, but you should know going into this that the game is short.
This is a fantastic puzzle game with smart graphics and good background music. A really simple concept executed very well.
Amazing game for short-time breaks: good, peaceful music, interesting puzzles and it does make you enjoy your time.

Product received for free

This game was gifted by Plobh.

There are about 80-90 short puzzles in this game. Even though you can only execute 3 different actions - activate, erase, pin - these puzzles are incredibly diverse. While most of them are quite easy, I couldn't solve some of the last 10 puzzles without a guide because they made my run out of hints.

According to Steam, beating the game took me about 75 minutes. Without a guide it might have been about 100 minutes. Without using any hints at all it might have taken 2-3 hours. In the end, it's a short game, no matter how you play it - but it's fun and worth the 3$ for sure.

TransPlan is a pretty decent puzzle/problem-solving game that should provide at least 2 to 3 hours of playtime to complete all levels and earn all of the achievements.  It's certainly not amazing, but I originally played through the game on mobile, and I must have enjoyed it enough that I decided to complete all the levels again on Steam.  If you like challenging puzzles, and you can pick up the game with a discount or in a bundle, you could do a lot worse than TransPlan.
